pageProps.contentHtml:
Cauchy's integral formula, Fubini's theorem

Let μ\muμ be a finite positive Borel measure on the complex plane C\CC.

  1. Prove that F(z)=∫C1z−w dμ(w)F\p{z} = \int_\C \frac{1}{z - w} \,\diff\mu\p{w}F(z)=∫C​z−w1​dμ(w) exists for almost all z∈Cz \in \Cz∈C and that ∫K∣F(z)∣ dx dy<∞\int_K \abs{F\p{z}} \,\diff{x} \,\diff{y} < \infty∫K​∣F(z)∣dxdy<∞ for every compact K⊆CK \subseteq \CK⊆C.

  2. Using (1), prove that for almost every horizontal line LLL (almost everywhere measured by yyy intercept), and all compact K⊆LK \subseteq LK⊆L, ∫K∣F(x+iy)∣ dx<∞\int_K \abs{F\p{x + iy}} \,\diff{x} < \infty∫K​∣F(x+iy)∣dx<∞.

  3. By "almost all squares in C\CC" we mean all squares in C\CC with sides parallel to the axes except for those squares whose lower left and and upper right vertices (z1,z2)\p{z_1, z_2}(z1​,z2​) belong to a Lebesgue measure zero subset of C2\C^2C2. Prove that for almost all open squares SSS,

    μ(S)=12πi∫∂SF(z) dz.\mu\p{S} = \frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{\partial S} F\p{z} \,\diff{z}.μ(S)=2πi1​∫∂S​F(z)dz.

    Hint: Use (2) and the analogous result for vertical lines.
Solution.

  1. It suffices to prove the second claim, since it implies that for each compact KKK, ∣F(z)∣<∞\abs{F\p{z}} < \infty∣F(z)∣<∞ almost everywhere on KKK, i.e., F(z)F\p{z}F(z) converges almost everywhere on KKK, so F(z)F\p{z}F(z) converges almost everywhere on C\CC.

    We may assume without loss of generality that K=B(0,R)‾K = \cl{B\p{0, R}}K=B(0,R)​. Indeed, any compact set is contained within such a ball if RRR is large enough, and we get the result by monotonicity.

    By applying Fubini-Tonelli, we may switch the order of integration in the following calculation:

    ∫B(0,R)‾∣F(z)∣ dA≤∫∣z∣≤R∫w∈C1∣z−w∣ dμ(w) dA(z)=∫w∈C∫∣z∣≤R1∣z−w∣ dA(z) dμ(w)=∫∣w∣≤2R∫∣z∣≤R1∣z−w∣ dA(z) dμ(w)+∫∣w∣>2R∫∣z∣≤R1∣z−w∣ dA(z) dμ(w)≤∫∣w∣≤2R∫∣z∣≤R1∣z−w∣ dA(z) dμ(w)+∫∣w∣>2R∫∣z∣≤R1R dA(z) dμ(w)≤∫∣w∣≤2R∫∣z−w∣≤3R1∣z−w∣ dA(z) dμ(w)+∫∣w∣>2R∫∣z∣≤R1R dA(z) dμ(w)=∫∣w∣≤2R∫03R∫02πrr dr dθ dμ(w)+∫∣w∣>2RπR dμ(w)=∫∣w∣≤2R6πR dμ(w)+∫∣w∣>2RπR dμ(w)=6πRμ(∣w∣≤2R)+πRμ(∣w∣>2R)<∞.\begin{aligned} \int_{\cl{B\p{0,R}}} \abs{F\p{z}} \,\diff{A} &\leq \int_{\abs{z} \leq R} \int_{w \in \C} \frac{1}{\abs{z - w}} \,\diff\mu\p{w} \,\diff{A}\p{z} \\ &= \int_{w \in \C} \int_{\abs{z} \leq R} \frac{1}{\abs{z - w}} \,\diff{A}\p{z} \,\diff\mu\p{w} \\ &= \int_{\abs{w} \leq 2R} \int_{\abs{z} \leq R} \frac{1}{\abs{z - w}} \,\diff{A}\p{z} \,\diff\mu\p{w} + \int_{\abs{w} > 2R} \int_{\abs{z} \leq R} \frac{1}{\abs{z - w}} \,\diff{A}\p{z} \,\diff\mu\p{w} \\ &\leq \int_{\abs{w} \leq 2R} \int_{\abs{z} \leq R} \frac{1}{\abs{z - w}} \,\diff{A}\p{z} \,\diff\mu\p{w} + \int_{\abs{w} > 2R} \int_{\abs{z} \leq R} \frac{1}{R} \,\diff{A}\p{z} \,\diff\mu\p{w} \\ &\leq \int_{\abs{w} \leq 2R} \int_{\abs{z - w} \leq 3R} \frac{1}{\abs{z - w}} \,\diff{A}\p{z} \,\diff\mu\p{w} + \int_{\abs{w} > 2R} \int_{\abs{z} \leq R} \frac{1}{R} \,\diff{A}\p{z} \,\diff\mu\p{w} \\ &= \int_{\abs{w} \leq 2R} \int_0^{3R} \int_0^{2\pi} \frac{r}{r} \,\diff{r} \,\diff\theta \,\diff\mu\p{w} + \int_{\abs{w} > 2R} \pi R \,\diff\mu\p{w} \\ &= \int_{\abs{w} \leq 2R} 6\pi R \,\diff\mu\p{w} + \int_{\abs{w} > 2R} \pi R \,\diff\mu\p{w} \\ &= 6\pi R\mu\p{\abs{w} \leq 2R} + \pi R\mu\p{\abs{w} > 2R} \\ &< \infty. \end{aligned}∫B(0,R)​​∣F(z)∣dA​≤∫∣z∣≤R​∫w∈C​∣z−w∣1​dμ(w)dA(z)=∫w∈C​∫∣z∣≤R​∣z−w∣1​dA(z)dμ(w)=∫∣w∣≤2R​∫∣z∣≤R​∣z−w∣1​dA(z)dμ(w)+∫∣w∣>2R​∫∣z∣≤R​∣z−w∣1​dA(z)dμ(w)≤∫∣w∣≤2R​∫∣z∣≤R​∣z−w∣1​dA(z)dμ(w)+∫∣w∣>2R​∫∣z∣≤R​R1​dA(z)dμ(w)≤∫∣w∣≤2R​∫∣z−w∣≤3R​∣z−w∣1​dA(z)dμ(w)+∫∣w∣>2R​∫∣z∣≤R​R1​dA(z)dμ(w)=∫∣w∣≤2R​∫03R​∫02π​rr​drdθdμ(w)+∫∣w∣>2R​πRdμ(w)=∫∣w∣≤2R​6πRdμ(w)+∫∣w∣>2R​πRdμ(w)=6πRμ(∣w∣≤2R)+πRμ(∣w∣>2R)<∞.​

  2. As before, it suffices to prove this for closed balls [−R,R]⊆L\br{-R, R} \subseteq L[−R,R]⊆L.

    Apply (1) and Fubini-Tonelli to K=[−M,M]×[n,n+1]K = \br{-M, M} \times \br{n, n+1}K=[−M,M]×[n,n+1], where n∈Zn \in \Zn∈Z, M∈NM \in \NM∈N, which gives ∫nn+1∫−MM∣F(x+iy)∣ dy dx<∞\int_n^{n+1} \int_{-M}^M \abs{F\p{x + iy}} \,\diff{y} \,\diff{x} < \infty∫nn+1​∫−MM​∣F(x+iy)∣dydx<∞. Thus, for almost every y∈[n,n+1]y \in \br{n, n+1}y∈[n,n+1], we have ∫−MM∣F(x+iy)∣ dx<∞\int_{-M}^M \abs{F\p{x + iy}} \,\diff{x} < \infty∫−MM​∣F(x+iy)∣dx<∞. Call this full measure set YnRY_n^RYnR​ and set

    Yn=⋂M∈NYnM.Y_n = \bigcap_{M \in \N} Y_n^M.Yn​=M∈N⋂​YnM​.

    Notice that

    m(Ync∩[k,k+1])≤∑k∈Zm((YnM)c∩[k,k+1])=0,m\p{Y_n^\comp \cap \br{k, k+1}} \leq \sum_{k\in\Z} m\p{\p{Y_n^M}^\comp \cap \br{k, k+1}} = 0,m(Ync​∩[k,k+1])≤k∈Z∑​m((YnM​)c∩[k,k+1])=0,

    so taking a union over k∈Zk \in \Zk∈Z, we see that YncY_n^\compYnc​ has Lebesgue measure zero. Moreover, if y∈Yny \in Y_ny∈Yn​, then ∫−MM∣F(x+iy)∣ dx<∞\int_{-M}^M \abs{F\p{x + iy}} \,\diff{x} < \infty∫−MM​∣F(x+iy)∣dx<∞. Thus, if we set

    Y=⋃n∈ZYn,Y = \bigcup_{n\in\Z} Y_n,Y=n∈Z⋃​Yn​,

    then YcY^\compYc also has Lebesgue measure zero as a countable intersection of measure zero sets.

    Finally, let R>0R > 0R>0 and y∈Yy \in Yy∈Y. If M∈NM \in \NM∈N is such that R≤MR \leq MR≤M, then by definition of YYY,

    ∫−RR∣F(x+iy)∣ dx≤∫−MM∣F(x+iy)∣ dx<∞,\int_{-R}^R \abs{F\p{x + iy}} \,\diff{x} \leq \int_{-M}^M \abs{F\p{x + iy}} \,\diff{x} < \infty,∫−RR​∣F(x+iy)∣dx≤∫−MM​∣F(x+iy)∣dx<∞,

    which proves the claim.

  3. Notice that in (1), we proved that ∫K1∣z−w∣ dA<∞\int_K \frac{1}{\abs{z - w}} \,\diff{A} < \infty∫K​∣z−w∣1​dA<∞ for any compact set KKK. Thus, by replacing ∣F(z)∣\abs{F\p{z}}∣F(z)∣ with ∫C1∣z−w∣ dμ(w)\int_\C \frac{1}{\abs{z - w}} \,\diff\mu\p{w}∫C​∣z−w∣1​dμ(w) in (2), we see that for almost every horizontal line LLL in C\CC that

    ∫K∫w∈C1∣(x+iy)−w∣ dμ(w) dx<∞\int_K \int_{w \in \C} \frac{1}{\abs{\p{x + iy} - w}} \,\diff\mu\p{w} \,\diff{x} < \infty∫K​∫w∈C​∣(x+iy)−w∣1​dμ(w)dx<∞

    for any compact K⊆LK \subseteq LK⊆L.

    If we run the same argument in (2) but with xxx and yyy switched, we obtain the analogous result for vertical lines with conull sets XXX for vertical lines and YYY for horizontal ones.

    Let SSS be the set of squares in C\CC whose vertices in X×YX \times YX×Y, so SSS contains almost every square in C\CC. Then in particular, we may integrate ∣F(z)∣\abs{F\p{z}}∣F(z)∣ along ∂S\partial S∂S. Combining this with our remark at the beginning, we may apply Fubini's theorem:

    12πi∫∂SF(z) dz=12πi∫∂S∫w∈C1z−w dμ(w) dz=∫w∈C(12πi∫∂S1z−w dz) dμ(w)=∫w∈CχS dμ=μ(S),\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{\partial S} F\p{z} \,\diff{z} &= \frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{\partial S} \int_{w \in \C} \frac{1}{z - w} \,\diff\mu\p{w} \,\diff{z} \\ &= \int_{w \in \C} \p{\frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{\partial S} \frac{1}{z - w} \,\diff{z}} \,\diff\mu\p{w} \\ &= \int_{w \in \C} \chi_S \,\diff\mu \\ &= \mu\p{S}, \end{aligned}2πi1​∫∂S​F(z)dz​=2πi1​∫∂S​∫w∈C​z−w1​dμ(w)dz=∫w∈C​(2πi1​∫∂S​z−w1​dz)dμ(w)=∫w∈C​χS​dμ=μ(S),​

    where the second-to-last equality comes from Cauchy's integral formula, and this gives us the desired result.
